Description: Egyptian terracotta figure plaque of naked woman (Isis-Hathor?) holding tambourine. Legs missing. Mould-made and solid. Dark red-brown Nile silt fabric with grey core. Abundant fine gold mica, quartz, organics and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Simple naked female plaque figures are common in Egypt during the Late Period and in the Levant at contemporary Phoenician sites. Parallels are generally dated to the Late Period and early Ptolemaic periods in Egypt. Thought to be fertility figures or ex-voto in honour of, but not representing, Hathor (Török 1995, pl.109, nos 203-9, particularly no.208; Bayer-Niemeier 1988, 148, no.263-7, for wig, see no. 265; Weber 1914, no.199; Petrie 1909, pl.35.7 and 11 from Memphis; Kaufmann 1913, fig. 69:3). Tambourine players with Egyptian wigs are common figurine forms from Cyprus and Samos in the 6th century BC (Karageorghis 1999, pl.51.5-6 #VI(ii)10-11). Bayer-Niemeier identifies a clear ‘Pharaonic tradition’ clear with New Kingdom and Third Intermediate Period parallels from Medinet Habu (Teeter 2010, nos 1 to 9 and 24 to 26) and the Temple of Mut in Luxor (Waraksa 2009, no. 3) and similar examples of this Pharaonic tradition come from New Kingdom domestic religion parallels from Deir el-Medina, Sawâma and Amarna (ibid.). Similar figure plaques found at Naukratis in the British Museum (Bailey 2008, nos 3108 to 3110; Higgins 1954, 404; GR 1888,0601.113, GR1886,0401.1543, GR 1886,0401.1458), Cambridge (NA576, NA577, NA578, NA579, NA581, NA582, NA583, NA584, especially NA589), and by recent excavations at Naukratis by the Supreme Council of Archaeology, (SCA), (unpublished). Bayer-Niemeier, E. 1988. Liebieghaus Museum Alter Plastik. Bildwerke der Sammlung Kaufmann, 1. Griechisch-römische Terrakotten. Melsungen. Karageorghis, J. 1999. The coroplastic art of ancient Cyprus.V. The Cypro-Archaic Period small female figurines. Nicosia, University of Cyprus. Petrie, W.M.F. 1909a. Memphis volume I. London, School of Archaeology in Egypt. Kaufmann, C. M. 1913, Ägyptische Terrakotten der griechisch-römischen und koptischen Epoche, Cairo. Teeter, E. 2010. Baked clay figurines and votive beds from Medinet Habu. Oriental Institute Publications 133, Chicago. Török, L. 1995. Hellenistic and Roman terracottas from Egypt. Roma. Waraksa, E. A. 2009. Female figurines from the Mut Precinct: context and ritual function. Fribourg Academic Press, Göttingen. Weber, W. 1914, Die ägyptisch-griechischen Terrakotten. Königliche Museen zu Berlin, Mitteilungen aus der Ägyptischen Sammlung II., Berlin.
